newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU to continue cosmetic tests on animals.
newsitem.headline: EU to continue cosmetic tests on animals.

text.p: The European Union decided on Thursday to extend testing of cosmetics products on animals until June 2000 because there were no other methods, a European Commission spokesman said.
Cosmetic tests on animals were due to be ended in January 1998 under an EU law approved in 1993.
"The Commission proposed extending the deadline because valid and recognised alternative tests have not yet been developed," the spokesman said.
But he added that in-vitro testing for eye and skin irritation would be ready by 2000.
The proposal was adopted by the EU Committee on the Adaptation to Technical Progress, chaired by the Commission and made up of officials from the 15 member states.
Animal welfare activists condemned the EU decision saying it meant further suffering for thousands of animals.
"It's a shame. The EU is blocking and sabotaging humane legislation," said Michel Vandenbosch, of the Global Action in the Interest of Animals (GAIA).
Vandenbosch, who said that cosmetics companies could use more than 8,000 existing ingredients to develop new products, was sceptical that animal testing would be banned in 2000.
Britain's Body Shop also condemned the EU decision.
"It's a disgrace. They are ignoring the overwhelming view of people throughout Europe who want these tests banned," Anita Roddick, The Body Shop's chief executive and founder, said in a statement.

In November, The Body Shop and the European Coalition to End Animal Testing presented the Commission and European Parliament with a petition bearing more than four million signatures, calling for cosmetic tests on animals to be banned from 1998.
